I believe that a course that attempts to provide an "introduction to global affairs" is inherently prone to two pitfalls: either it focusses too singularly on one topic or region (and thus is not truly "global") or covers too much, very superficially. Unfortunately I think this course to some extent did both of these things.
The first half of the semester focussed entirely on the Middle East with a heavy focus on the US (and, to a lesser extent, the West in general) perspective of those affairs. This seemed to pander to a US audience, which I recognize must be the majority given Yale's location, but I felt that this narrowness undermined the attempt of the course to teach global issues. The second half of the semester covered a range of topics. These topics were heavily weighted towards those directly related to the US and especially US national security - for example, a lecture on "Russia" was actually a lecture on US-Russia relations and China was largely framed in the context of the US-China trade war. Unfortunately when handling topics that were not directly related to the US, a degree of ignorance on the part of the class was assumed, resulting in a highly superficial discussion that was largely just based on very generalized, basic facts - the lecture on Conflict and Justice in Africa was a prime example of this. 
I would argue that the assessment model further entrenched this narrow perspective and hindered students' active engagement and opportunity to learn from this class. The midterm papers were too short for students to be able to properly discuss and critically analyze their ideas, and the assessment criteria did not encourage students to extend themselves by doing further research and engaging with current affairs beyond the scope of class material. These elements would have allowed students to broaden their perspectives and also would have allowed them to engage with the matters most important to them: it is essential to recognize that students take this class from a wide range of fields and interests and it would be ideal to allow them to explore these in their assessments beyond what is able to be covered in class. The assessments were also very narrowly defined in their real-world application: the "policy" assessments were restricted to the US government and the UN, and thus prevented students from exploring other mechanisms to create change (such as technological innovation summits or community-based organizations and projects). Allowing more innovative solutions would have definitely broadened the scope for students to engage in a more realistic and less US-centric approach to global affairs.
I also felt that the assessments were too leniently graded, resulting in a lack of constructive criticism. I did not feel that I really learned anything by doing the assessments; instead, I simply regurgitated information and opinions I had been fed in class.
